user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UtSprintf:
```c
char *UtSprintf(const char *Spec, ...)
{
    va_list                     Args;
    static UT_Snprintf_Buffer_t Buf[UT_SNPRINTF_MAX_BUFS];
    static uint32               TextIndex = 0;

    ++TextIndex;
    if (TextIndex >= UT_SNPRINTF_MAX_BUFS)
        TextIndex = 0;

    va_start(Args, Spec);
    vsnprintf(Buf[TextIndex].Text, sizeof(Buf[TextIndex].Text), Spec, Args);
    va_end(Args);

    return Buf[TextIndex].Text;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function UtSprintf:
typedef struct
{
    char Text[UT_SNPRINTF_BUF_SIZE];
} UT_Snprintf_Buffer_t
...
#define UT_SNPRINTF_MAX_BUFS 10
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
++TextIndex;
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation. The fragment ++TextIndex itself does not call any <string.h> function and does not, by itself, cause a string handling function to access beyond buffer bounds. In the shown code the increment is immediately followed by a bounds-check (if (TextIndex >= UT_SNPRINTF_MAX_BUFS) TextIndex = 0;) before Buf[TextIndex].Text is used by vsnprintf, so the index used for the buffer access will be in range. (Note: concurrent calls to UtSprintf without synchronization could lead to race conditions and out‑of‑range indexing, but that is a thread-safety issue, not a direct violation of MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 which concerns use of <string.h> functions.)
